Posts.Content: I'm relatively new here, too but have found that this is the place to be for both information and compassion. I have never been let down when I've asked for help and I thank everyone who has taken the time to respond to my emails. So I wish good luck to you and happiness everyday.
Posts.Title: surgery

Posts.Content: I wrote to this forum on 5/24/09 discussing my recent diagnosis of breast cancer. I cannot believe it took until today for me to find all of the kind messages that were sent my way. I don't quite know how the site works yet but I will come back. I want to thank all of the people who gave me advice, sent prayers my way, and offered me options, ones that I would not have considered on my own. Thank you cancercompass. peggypraying
Posts.Title: Thanks to all

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with DCIS two years ago. Underwent a mastectomy. No chemo/radiation. Recently, I underwent a stereotactic biopsy for a suspicious microcalcification. It was found to be benign, however I'm told that I have a papilloma in my existing breast and need to see my surgeon immediately. Has anyone else been given any news of this nature? I've been told it's noncancerous, so I don't understand why I need to see the surgeon. Thank you for any help you can offer.
Posts.Title: Breast papilloma

Posts.Content: On Jun 02, 2011 3:40 AM KarieB wrote: I am so very sorry I missed seeing your post earlier.  What a really scary spot you were in having the history you did. I am praying your results were good and if not, that you are now recovering from surgery that removed everything bad.  I am a 14 year survivor of ER- breast cancer.  Like you, I had breast calcifications and a diagnosis of non-invasive DCIS.   My treatment was a  modified radical mastectomy with TRAM reconstruction and breast reduction surgery on the other side, all at the same time as I knew I would be too chicken to go back for reconstruction later.   Like you, I had no chemo or radiation.  I go for blood tests and followup checks every six months and once a year mammograms.  I have experienced no other problems with it so far but remain ever vigilant.  I will keep you in my prayers and hope to see an update on your situation soon. Karie Dear KarieB: Glad I checked in and saw your message. I appreciate your input. Have not yet had the surgery. The powers that be have made me wait 50 days. I'll come back with results when I finally get them. Our stories are so very similar. It lifts my spirits that you are doing so well after 14 years. I hope to follow your lead in this journey we're both on. Thank you so much for replying. It calms me down.
Posts.Title: Just need to talk

Posts.Content: Two years ago I was diagnosed with non-invasive DCIS in my left breast due to cancerous breast calcifications. After a mastectomy I was found to be ER-/PR-/Her2positive. No chemo/radiation because of the negative/positive status. Clear margins. Now, two years later I am faced with a suspicious calcification in my right breast and am scheduled for a stereotactic biopsy in one week. I am nervous and don't know where to turn to in order to speak to anyone. Is there anyone else on this site who has been in a similar situation? I would appreciate any shared stories I can get. Thank you.
Posts.Title: Just need to talk

Posts.Content: I found out a week ago or so that the suspicious mammo was not the cancerous microcalcification that had been feared. It was a benign papilloma AND a fibroid adenoma which they didn't expect to find when they cut out the papilloma! Even though all appears well at this time, I am at my wit's end because I have been begging to get a second mastectomy for a couple of years but my surgeon, onc, and primary physician have all denied me. They say there's nothing wrong. Wait and see. That's what they continue to tell me. Additionally, I'm still not even being given the option of taking any meds. I know from reading this forum that this is unusual and I feel that I'm being played. I am certainly grateful for my current status, but it seems like because I have insurance, I am at the mercy of the medical world. No decisions are my own. Thank you for sharing your story with me. I wish you only the best and hope that all works out well for you. Fingers crossed for both of us and all of those others who are dealing with this disease.
Posts.Title: Just need to talk

It was a benign papilloma AND a fibroid adenoma which they didn't expect to find when they cut out the papilloma! Even though all appears well at this time, I am at my wit's end because I have been begging to get a second mastectomy for a couple of years but my surgeon, onc, and primary physician have all denied me. Posts.Title: Just need to talk

Posts.Content: Thank you, Yaziza. I will keep you updated. Sometimes just writing things down helps. I appreciate your response very, very much. Best wishes to your brother's girlfriend and, of course, to your father.
Posts.Title: Just need to talk

Posts.Content: On Jun 02, 2011 3:06 AM OKnow wrote: Dear peggypraying - I hope you got good news on the tests. The scariest part (for me at least) is that the cancer always seems to be lurking in the background - like a stalker. I was also ER-/PR-, but got chemo and bilateral mastectomy. PET scan showed BC clear, buy showed something in my digestive system. So, we'll get working on that next. Just wanted to let you know I'm thinking of you and hope the worries fade with each good checkup. Dear OKnow: Thank you for asking about me. I am scheduled for a needle loc excisional breast biopsy followed by the removal of the papilloma in one week. It seems that once I take a step forward that old cancer scare is right behind me. I am curious that you were able to get chemo and bilateral mastectomy. I was absolutely refused by two oncologists. Makes me wonder but not worry. Past worrying now. Please let me know how you are doing. I so very much appreciate your checking in. Still waiting. The waiting is always the hardest part.
Posts.Title: Just need to talk

Posts.Content: I appreciate your kind thoughts, KarieB. I also appreciate your prayers. Yours is the first story I've heard that matches mine. I'm going to keep coming back to this site. Good people like you are here every single time I log on. Thank you, again.
Posts.Title: Just need to talk

Posts.Content: Yes, thank you! My prognosis turned out to be quite good. Precancerous, stage 0, NON-invasive. They all thought it was invasive. I underwent a total mastectomy and the reconstruction has begun via expander/saline injection. Soon I'll be going to the oncologist who has already told me I'll be on either Tamoxifen or Arimidex. So, I am here researching these drugs.  I am grateful to you for having taken the time to give me advice. This place is like heaven for people like me. Having other people who have gone through this struggle and having them be kind enough to offer advice and/or words of comfort is extraordinary. I thank you and hope you are well.
Posts.Title: What do you think?

Posts.Content: On 6/20/2009 kaybell wrote: I had a double mastectomy last July for breast cancer. I had reconstruction with an expander and saline inplant put in this March. I still have a fair amount of pain especially after doing any activity that uses my upper body. I have always been a gardener but many of the activities like pulling weeds, hoeing, using the rototiller, etc. leave me in pain. Will I ever get to where I can do these things again? I am feeling pretty depressed about this. I am thinking that I made a mistake by getting reconstruction. Has anyone else had this problem? Do I just need to give it more time? Deborah Hi Deborah: I feel I only have a bit of information to share regarding your post reconstruction pain as I got a total mastectomy with reconstruction only 2 weeks ago. I am going through the expander/saline injections and have to say that it is a strange feeling at best. The worst part would be the "pulling feeling" and hardness of the feeling of your reconstructed breasts. Though it's only been 2 weeks for me, I have a feeling that you will be able to overcome your pain soon. I am also a gardener and have already mowed my front and back lawns, pulled weeds and planted flower and vegetable gardens. When I get that "pulling" feeling, I put an ice pack on my breast and it tends to make me feel much better. I truly don't believe that you made a mistake. In the long run, I believe you will be glad that you decided to get the expander/saline treatment. Please consult your doctor. There must be something that he/she can tell you. Trust them. And I send you my well wishes. You are most certainly not alone in this. Peggy
Posts.Title: post reconstruction pain

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with DCIS, stage 0, non-invasive breast cancer 7 months ago. Results showed me to be ER-/PR- so no chemo/radiation or Tamoxifan or Arimedix. My oncologist told me that I was not triple negative as my cancer was non-invasive. I feel like I'm sort of left twisting in the wind without the use of a chemo pill or some sort of protection against cancer appearing somewhere else. Is there anyone else out there who shares my story? If so, could you please share your insights with me. It is much appreciated. Thank you.
Posts.Title: ER negative/PR negative

Posts.Content: I underwent a total mastectomy on my left breast yesterday which included reconstructive surgery. My breast surgeon informed me that three lymph nodes were removed for biopsy purposes. She also said that all preliminary indications show that they are negative. I will receive the pathology report next Monday. Do any of you think I should start to breathe again or is there a possibility that I should brace myself for more bad news? I started out with a precancerous, stage 0 diagnosis. Certainly could use the good advice I've gotten from all of you since I found this website. Thank you for any advice you can send my way.
Posts.Title: What do you think?

Posts.Content: I didn't even get Tamoxifin. I was diagnosed ER-/PR- but not triple negative. There is no medication for my status. Then my oncologist bailed on me because he didn't like my insurance company. I have no idea what to do next but my other docs have indicated that I have to stay vigilant checking my other breast as there is a good chance of a new cancer showing in my existing breast. I hope that the meds alone help you in your situation. In my opinion, it's good that you are getting some kind of treatment to keep the cancer cells at bay. Wishing you the best!
Posts.Title: tomaxofin and nothing else???
